title.narrative: National Program Support for Environment and Natural Resources Management Project

description.narrative: The development objective of the National Program Support for Environment and Natural Resources Management Project for Philippines is to assist the Department of Environment and Natural Resources (DENRs) to improve efficiency and effectiveness in its service delivery. More specifically, the project will aim to strengthen the allocative efficiency of DENR's limited budget resources through better prioritization and partnership arrangements, facilitating scaling up and better linking of plans and budgets. The closing date for the project will be extended from December 31, 2012 until December 31, 2013. The project has made very encouraging progress during the past year and was rated moderately satisfactory during the last implementation review mission in June 2012. Most of the 25 performance indicators have been fully or partially achieved. For the US$50 million loan, disbursements increased significantly from US$21.9 million in December 2011 to US$41.25 million currently. For the US$7 million Global Environment Facility (GEF) grant, disbursements are currently at US$5.0 million compared with US$2.9 million in December 2011. Major achievements include: progress on the DENR's reform agenda with rationalization plans prepared for several of its Bureaus and only awaiting DBM approval; completion of forest boundary delineation including production of maps; significant progress on the cadastral surveys; achievement of investment targets for the rehabilitation of ecosystems; advances in the Manila Bay clean-up activity; institutionalization of the management effectiveness tracking tool at all protected areas being supported by the project; standardized procedures for the issuance of tenure instruments; and increase in the number of companies complying with environmental standards. The project has also improved its performance on procurement and sustained that on financial mana

condition.narrative: Borrower through DENR shall complete implementation of the recommendations in its 2005 audit report in accordance with theFinancial Management Action Plan, in a manner satisfactory to the Bank.
By 06/30 & 12/31 of each CY, strtng 06/30/08, conduct semi-annual intrnl audits for Proj.accnts in scope & details acceptable toBank & thereafter furnish a rprt to Bank with its fndngs & recmmndtns.
Develop and immediately thereafter implement an action plan to improve DENR's information management system (MIS) and the publicaccess to DENR's information database.
Engage an external firm, with qualifications and experience and under terms of reference, acceptable to the Bank, to strengthenDENR's internal audit services.
Implement the aforementioned three (3) year forward-looking planning and budgeting strategy taking into account the Bank'scomments thereon.
Issue & thereafter implmnt an administrtve order to establish a procremnt unit within DENR, under TOR consistent with therequirements of the Borrower's Procurement Reform Act (Republic Act 9184).
Issue and thereafter implement an administrative order to enable its Internal Audit unit to report directly to the Secretary ofDENR, in line with the Borrower's anti-corruption initiatives.
Issue and thereafter implement an administrative order to restructure its Environment Management Bureau (EMB) and to staff therestructured EMB, all in accordance with DENR's Rationalization Plan.
Prep 3 yr plan/budget strategy with reform benchmarks in, PA/ENV/NRM/ abandoned mines rehab/ etc
Review with Bank the mid-term evaluation report and take all measures required to ensure the efficient completion of the projectand achievement of objectives.
Undertake a baseline study to measure client satisfaction with DENR's service delivery.
Undertake a follow-up study to baseline study to compare the effectiveness of measures undertaken by DENR during the Projectperiodto improve client satisfaction in regard to its service delivery.
furnish to the Bank, not later than March 31 in each year starting March 31, 2008 for review and comments, an annual work plan andbudget for the implementation of the project in the following year
prepare under TOR satisfactory to the Bank, and furnish to the Bank a mid-term evaluation report integrating the results of themonitoring and evaluation activities performed.

title.narrative: 106,000 hectares of protected areas, protection forest and wetlands in GEF supported sites under effective management by PY5 as measured by the PA management effectiveness tool

comment.narrative: Baseline area not under effective management.
Core indicator equivalent (forest area brought under effective management) METT implemented in PAs in all GEF sites though only131,886 ha. covered

title.narrative: 35% of ecologically sensitive forests (outside protected areas) under effective protection as identified in each WMP

comment.narrative: Baseline estimated as part of the Client Satisfaction Survey as total area of ecologically sensitive forests.
Achieved: 131,886 ha under effective protection

title.narrative: 25% decline in the area under kaingin (as measured by no. of plots) as a result of project intervention

comment.narrative: Baseline proved to be un-mesurable
Indicator proved to be un-measurable
Continued monitoring the existing stations
273 stations now being monitored with 100% compliance.

title.narrative: 15% reduction in total suspended particulate matter levels in Metro Manila over the 2007 baseline

comment.narrative: Expressed in μg/NCM. Similar to core indicator with different unit of measurement and number of people affected not monitored.
Expressed in μg/NCM
Expressed in μg/NCM. Target of 15% reduction, 25% achieved.

title.narrative: Forest area brought under management plans

comment.narrative: GEF protected areas adopt METT
METT has been adopted at all 4 GEF protected area sites.
Rehabilitate at least 30% of forest outside GEF sites
Comprises 71,807 ha of initial 100,000 ha targeted plus 311,581 planted under the NGP since 2011.

title.narrative: ENR fees/royalties operational in at least 2 watershed areas

target.value: PES operational in at least 2 sites

comment.narrative: TA on PES has been provided, studies done, and a Compendium of Case studies prepared. While user fees/environmental service feesare being collected in a number of Protected Areas, difficulties have been experience in implementing PES suggesting more policyguidance is needed. An important development has been the passage of a law requiring 75% automatic retention by DENR of earningsfrom Protected Areas, providing both a source of funds for maintaining PAs and an incentive mechanism to promote PES.

title.narrative: Implementation of DENR's reform agenda, which includes timely actions on the dated covenants, achievement of the key milestones andcontinued progress in implementing the Rationalization Plan

baseline.value: Reform Agenda agreed for NPS-ENRMP in line with Rationalization Plan. Dated covenants provided in the loan for key actions.

target.value: Key milestones have been met Dated loan covenants complied with and under implementation.

comment.narrative: EMB, MGB & DENR now implementing Rationalization Plan approved by DBM on Oct 16, 2013. Key institutional reforms which werecovenanted under the project were achieved to the extent they were within DENR's control, eg. procurement capacity increased,internal audit unit estd., 3 yr forward plan and expenditure program prepared

title.narrative: Framework for the rationalization of NRM&E policies and legislation developed and under implementation

baseline.value: Various studies available highlighting inconsistencies in legislation, policy and implementation

target.value: Action plan being implemented to rationalize the ENR policies and legislation

comment.narrative: Framework developed and being updated in line with new priorities. Joint issuances by DENR with DAR, LRA, DLG and NCIP were madetoclarify respective jurisdictions, policies, programs, projects, etc, harmonize implementation of Indigenous Peoples Reform Actand ENR laws.

title.narrative: 80% of the Project's investment targets in rehabilitation, ecosystem development and assessments being met

comment.narrative: Achieved: LGUs have CAF for 96% of $4m GEF grant. Project target of 30% of non-GEF degraded forests rehabilitated met throughNational Greening Program

Assessments have been finalized for all 5 sites (encompassing soil & water analysis, geotechnical/geo-hazard assessment,information, education & communication, flora & fauna, air quality and acid mine drainage).

title.narrative: Monitor 1600 companies along water bodies draining into Manila Bay

comment.narrative: Achieved. both the number of companies and their compliance increased.
Both the number of companies issued permits and their compliance with requirements increased.

title.narrative: Monitor 101 bathing beaches for their bacterial levels/safety

comment.narrative: Achieved.

title.narrative: Monitor 4216 environmentall critical projects issued with Environmental Compliance Certificate

comment.narrative: Achieved

title.narrative: Forward planning and budgeting strategy started to be implemented which inter alia provides a vision and benchmarks for key reformsin DENRs operations

baseline.value: DBM instruction has been isused requiring OPIFs to be prepared by all departments

target.value: Close linkage between Plans and Budgets

comment.narrative: 2010-2012 Medium Term Expenditure Program by sector was completed. Major expenditure items for each MFO consistent with NPS-ENRMPindicators.

i) Cadastral maps have been prepared for 814 (50%) of municipalities in the country. These maps provide the cadastral informationfor alienable and disposable public lands and are essential for resolving the many competing claims on A&D lands. Completion ofcadastral mapping is scheduled for 2015. The maps will be of considerable value to LGUs and are inputs to the Bank assisted LAMP2project (additional financing). ii) Forest boundary delineation has been completed for 75 provinces and two cities, encompassing79,245 Square Km. DENR has been proactive in following-up/advocacy for 68 draft bills to define forest boundaries. The maps wererequired by the legislature as a prerequisite for the legal definition of forest boundaries.

title.narrative: PA rules and regulations updated and streamlined and revised policy issued.

baseline.value: Lack of clarity in procedures for CBRMA/CBFMA and NIPAS has virtually resulted in a cessation of this instrument

target.value: Increases in issuance of CBRMA/CBFMAs and NIPAS-IRR

comment.narrative: NIPAS-IRR updated, streamlined & policy issued

title.narrative: Key databases on line for public access

comment.narrative: Connection of DENR offices and bureaus through Voice Over Internet Protocol (VOIP) is largely completed. The system willfacilitatemonitoring and reporting as well as updating of databases, land records etc. Procurement for construction of a “GreenData Center”designed to house and integrate all DENR data bases is underway. The enhancement of “Service Delivery” through on-linepublic accessibility to databases e.g. relating to industrial use, forests and protected areas has yet to be established.

title.narrative: Mapping of priority geo-hazard areas completed

comment.narrative: All of the planned 1,634 geo-hazard maps at a scale of 1:50,000 have been completed. Completion of smaller scale maps (1:10,000)should be completed in 2014. The maps are increasingly being used to help prepare LGUs and national agencies through informationon flood/landslide prone areas, especially in advance of typhoons as part of risk mitigation measures.

title.narrative: 60% of targeted communities in GEF supported sites implementing micro-catchment plans by the end of the Project

comment.narrative: All targeted municipalities implementing micro catchment plans

Interim rehabilitation has been achieved through construction of diversion channel/pipeline, maintenance of limestone dam andore/waste stockpile dam, construction of laboratory building as well as research on phyto-remediation and maintenance of the70-hectare reforestation area around the site. Ongoing activities beyond the project include: (i) completion of Geo-technicalStudy, (ii) implementation of Environmental Management Plan, and (iii) re-vegetation /reforestation of 100 ha (to be completed in2016).

title.narrative: Best management practices replicated in at least 2 non GEF sites*Core Indicator: Reforms in forest policy, legislation or other regulations supported

comment.narrative: The IEM approach is being replicated as part of the National Convergence Initiative (DENR-DA-DAR) and is being undertaken in thewatersheds of Quinali R-5, Pola & Bongabong R-4B. Other foreign assisted project are also adopting the approach e.g., USAIDsupportedBiodiversity and Watersheds Improved for Stronger Economy and Resiliency Project (B+WISER) & GiZ's EnRD Project in Region8.

title.narrative: Watershed management councils established and MOAs in place between DENR and LGUs and between LGUs and NGOs

comment.narrative: Watershed Management Councils exist for all GEF sites along with MOAs with DENR - LGUs and LGUs with Peoples Organizations

title.narrative: 128 LGUs are implementing three aspects of ecological solid waste management

comment.narrative: Core indicator equivalent (Industrial or municipal solid waste reduced or recycled under the project) Out of 112 LGUs, 88%implementing segregation at source; 84% practice segregated collection, and 78% operate MRFs. 3 LGUs exempted due to impact ofdisasters

title.narrative: 100% of GEF supported protected areas (PA) mainstreamed PA management effectiveness tool

baseline.value: Tools not in use at any sites

comment.narrative: Core indicator equivalent (Forest area brought under management plans) Tool in use at all sites

title.narrative: Designation and operationalization of at least 3 water quality management areas

comment.narrative: 3 WQMAs established i) Meycauayan-Marilao-Obando- R3, Jaro-Tigum-Aganan R-6 & Saranggani Bay-R12. Each has a Governing Board and10- year WQMA action plan.

title.narrative: 75 % of funded activities (by $ value) in GEF supported sites implemented by the LGUs and/or other stakeholders

comment.narrative: Core indicator equivalent (people in targeted forest and adjacent communities with increased monetary and non-monetary benefitsfrom forests). All funded activities in the GEF sites implemented with active participation of LGU and other stakeholders

title.narrative: 30% of households in GEF sites adopt livelihood practices

comment.narrative: 6,810 households benefited out of estimated 77,152, 96% of funds used. Target overestimated for the available project resources.

title.narrative: 30% improvement in overall client satisfaction with DENR service delivery by type of client e.g. LGU/communities.

comment.narrative: Follow up survey incomplete, now to be completed post-project - March 2014 using DENR own funds.

title.narrative: 10% per annum increase in companies complying with environmental standards compared to baseline

baseline.value: Year 1 level: air 55% and water 37% compliance

actual.value: 29% air; 26 % water increase over 2008 up to 2011; 2012 not yet available

comment.narrative: Core indicator equivalent (Particulate matter reduction under the project (microgram/m3))

title.narrative: 30% of degraded forest in GEF supported sites rehabilitated with native species representing the bio-geographic region as identified in the WMP

comment.narrative: Core indicator: area restored. Rehab. Of 9525 ha (planned target may have been over estimated given available resources)
